results.headline: Review: ‘Blair Witch’: Don’t Go Back Into the Woods
results.summary_short: This follow-up to the 1999 hit “The Blair Witch Project” offers more gore, more gadgets and 89 minutes of screaming, flashlight waving and falling trees.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blair Witch

results.headline: Review: In ‘Southwest of Salem,’ 4 Women Convicted of Sexual Assault Fight for Justice
results.summary_short: The documentary bears witness to crucial moments, such as a relative’s recanted accusation, and persuasively argues that the charges against the women were implausible.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Southwest of Salem

results.headline: Review: ‘The Vessel’: Learning to Forge Ahead After Wrenching Loss
results.summary_short: Julio Quintana’s film centers on a young man who arouses ire when he sets out to build a boat after witnessing tragedies in his seaside village.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Vessel

results.display_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week
results.headline: Review: ‘The Beatles: Eight Days a Week’ Taking the World by Storm
results.summary_short: Ron Howard’s documentary explores the wild ride John, Paul, George and Ringo took in the early 1960s, helping to usher in the youth-culture age.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Beatles: Eight Days a Week

results.headline: Review: ‘Cardboard Boxer’: Homeless Man’s Redemption via a Diary
results.summary_short: Thomas Haden Church stars as a lonely skid row denizen whose life gains a new dimension after he finds a disheartened child’s diary.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cardboard Boxer

results.headline: Review: ‘A Family Affair,’ or Airing Dirty Laundry
results.summary_short: The Dutch documentarian Tom Fassaert pursues his own history, beginning with his 95-year-old grandmother in South Africa.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Family Affair

results.headline: Review: ‘Finding Altamira’: A Prehistoric Discovery, Vehemently Disputed
results.summary_short: Hugh Hudson’s drama about the uncovering of cave paintings features Antonio Banderas as the 19th-century Spaniard who fought to prove their authenticity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Finding Altamira

results.headline: Review: In ‘Hillsong — Let Hope Rise,’ a Strumming Ministry Packs in Crowds
results.summary_short: This sleepy documentary about Hillside United is a portrait of singing “worship leaders” and swaying fans who join in generic anthems at a Los Angeles concert.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hillsong — Let Hope Rise

results.display_title: Is That a Gun in Your Pocket?...
results.headline: Review: A Sex-or-Guns Comedy That Might Make Aristophanes Wince
results.summary_short: “Is That a Gun in Your Pocket?...” is a clumsy comedy that transports the premise of “Lysistrata” to small-town Texas, with a twist.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Is That a Gun in Your Pocket?...

results.headline: Review: ‘Silicon Cowboys’ Tracks the Rise of Compaq Computer
results.summary_short: This documentary grounds itself in people and technology as it tells the story of a company that was bold at an opportune time in the 1980s.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Silicon Cowboys

results.headline: Review: In ‘Tanna,’ Lovers Are Torn Apart to Keep Tribal Peace
results.summary_short: A romantic drama filmed in a remote part of Vanuatu, in the South Pacific, tells a “Romeo and Juliet” story with a cast of villagers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tanna

results.headline: Review: ‘Snowden,’ Oliver Stone’s Restrained Portrait of a Whistle-Blower
results.summary_short: This is a movie that does not dazzle or enrage in its evocation of recent history, but creates a cloud of discomfiting doubt.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Snowden

results.headline: Review: A Zany Renée Zellweger and Mystery Daddy in ‘Bridget Jones’s Baby’
results.summary_short: The latest film in this series revolves around the pregnancy of Ms. Zellweger’s character and the two dreamboats most likely to be the father.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bridget Jones's Baby

results.headline: Review: ‘Command and Control’: Common Errors, Nuclear Arms and Consequences
results.summary_short: The film documents a 1980 accident in a missile silo in Arkansas that showed just how vulnerable the nation’s most fearsome weapons can be.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Command and Control

results.headline: Review: ‘When the Bough Breaks,’ Blame a Scary Pregnancy Surrogate
results.summary_short: This movie, about a well-off couple and the woman they hire to carry their embryo, looks for suspense in a genre that has little left.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of When the Bough Breaks

results.headline: Review: In ‘Kicks,’ the Promise (and Perils) of Those Air Jordans
results.summary_short: This debut feature depicts a 15-year-old in a tough neighborhood who buys the shoes of his dreams — and the desperation he feels when they are taken from him.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kicks

results.headline: Review: In ‘Demon,’ Wedding Jitters From the Uninvited Dead
results.summary_short: A modern ghost story haunted by the Holocaust, this film by the Polish director Marcin Wrona reconceptualizes the Jewish mythology of the dybbuk.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Demon

results.headline: Review: In ‘As I Open My Eyes,’ Feeling a Revolution Coming
results.summary_short: A headstrong singer comes of age on the eve of Tunisia’s Jasmine Revolution.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of As I Open My Eyes

results.headline: Review: In ‘Cameraperson,’ a Found Poem Filtered Through an Intent Eye
results.summary_short: Kirsten Johnson’s riveting documentary flits from Bosnia to Darfur to ground zero and zigzags across time, prompting reflection on the nature of her art.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cameraperson

results.headline: Review: 5 Murdered Prostitutes and an Anxious City in ‘London Road’
results.summary_short: A spate of real-life murders in England in 2006 forms the basis of this film directed by Rufus Norris.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of London Road
